case_name: Vajrapani Naidu and Bangarammal v. New Theatre Carnatic Talkies Ltd., Coimbatore

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 264 of 1962 appealed from judgment and order dated April 24, 1959 of Madras High Court in L.P.A. No. 75 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 264 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 24, 1959 of the Madras High Court in L.P.A. No. 75 of 1958.

facts.text: Vajrapani Naidu and his mother Bangarammal granted a lease of an open site in Coimbatore to Abirama Chettiar under registered deed dated September 19, 1934 for 20 years at Rs. 1,080 annual rental for theatre.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH J.-The appellant Vajrapani Naidu and his mother Bangarammal-hereinafter collectively called the lessors- granted a lease of an open site in the town of Coimbatore to Abirama Chettiar under a registered deed dated September 19, 1934, for 20 years at an annual rental of Rs. 1,080/- for putting up a building suitable for use as a theatre.

facts.text: Abirama Chettiar constructed a theatre on the site and assigned rights to New Theatre Carnatic Talkies Ltd., Coimbatore (the Company).

anchor.surface_text: Abirama Chettiar constructed a theatre on the site, and assigned his rights to the New Theatre Carnatic Talkies Ltd., Coimbatore-hereinafter called the Company.

facts.text: The Company attorned to the lessors and was recognised as tenant under the lease dated September 19, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: The Company attorned to the lessors and was recognised as tenant under the lease dated September 19, 1934.

facts.text: On March 9, 1954 lessors served notice on Company to vacate and surrender vacant possession.

anchor.surface_text: On March 9, 1954 the lessors served a notice calling upon the Company to vacate and surrender vacant possession of the site,

facts.text: Company failed to comply, lessors commenced action for ejectment and mesne profits at Rs. 1,000 per month from September 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and the Company having failed to comply with the requisition, the lessors commenced an action against the Company for a decree in ejectment and for mesne profits at the rate of Rs. 1,000/- per mensem from September 19, 1954.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge at Coimbatore awarded decree for possession and mesne profits at Rs. 350 per month and costs.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge at Coimbatore awarded to the lessors a decree for possession and mesne profits at the rate of Rs. 350/- per mensem and costs of the suit.

facts.text: Company appealed to District Court at Coimbatore, transferred to Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decree the Company preferred an appeal to the District Court at Coimbatore which was transferred for trial to the High Court at Madras.

facts.text: During pendency of appeal, by G.O. No. 608 dated February 10, 1958, State of Madras extended Madras City Tenants Protection Act to Coimbatore.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this appeal by G.O. No. 608 dated February 10, 1958, the State of Madras extended the Madras City Tenants Protection Act 3 of 1922, as amended by Madras Act 19 of 1955, to the Municipal town of Coimbatore.

facts.text: Company applied under s.9 for order directing lessors to convey site for price fixed by Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Company then applied under s. 9 of the Act for an order directing the lessors to convey the site demised to the Company for a price to be fixed by the Court.

facts.text: Panchapakesa Iyer J. directed lessors to sell site under s.9 at full market value on date of order, trial court to appoint commissioner based on market value on July 28, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Panchapakesa lyer, J., directed that the lessors do sell to the Company the site in dispute under s. 9 of the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1922. against payment of the full market value of the land on the date of the order, and further directed that the trial Court do appoint a Commissioner to fix the value of the site based on the market value prevalent on July 28, 1958.

facts.text: Appeal under cl.15 Letters Patent against order of Panchapakesa Iyer J. dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal under cl. 15 of the Letters Patent of the High Court against the order of Panchapakesa lyer, J., was dismissed.

facts.text: High Court of Madras granted certificate, lessors preferred appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court of Madras, this appeal is preferred by the lessors.

facts.text: Lease was for vacant site in municipal town of Coimbatore, annual rent Rs. 1,080, 20 years from possession delivery.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary in the first instance to notice the material terms of the lease. The land demised under the lease was a vacant site situate in the municipal town of Coimbatore. The annual rent stipulated was Rs. 1,080/- - and the period of the lease was 20 years from the date of delivery of possession of the site.

facts.text: Land to be used for constructing buildings for cinema, drama etc.

anchor.surface_text: The land was to be utilised for constructing buildings thereon for purposes of Cinema, drama, etc

facts.text: Lessee had option of renewal for another 20 years on fresh terms.

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the term of 20 years stipulated under the deed the lessee had an option of renewal for another period of 20 years on fresh terms and conditions.

facts.text: Lease provided that on termination, lessee to pay arrears, dismantle constructions, deliver vacant site, else lessors right to possession through court after dismantling.

anchor.surface_text: The deed provided that if after the termination of the stipulated period the lessees fail to pay the arrears of rent that will fall due till that date and hand over possession of the site to the lessors after making it clear by dismantling the constructions therein and by demolishing the walls etc. the lessors shall, besides realizing the arrears of rent due to them according to law, have the right to take possession through Court of the site in which the aforesaid buildings are put up after dismantling the constructions and demolishing the buildings therein.

facts.text: Lease granted before Act extended to Coimbatore, buildings constructed after lease date, common ground.

anchor.surface_text: The lease granted by the lessors in this case was before the date on which the Act was extended to the Coimbatore municipal town and it is common ground that the buildings were constructed after the date of the contract of lease.

facts.text: Judgment delivered March 4, 1964 by Shah J. for majority, dissenting opinion by Ayyangar J.

anchor.surface_text: March 4, 1964. The Judgment of GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J., SHAH and SIKRI JJ. was delivered by Shah J. The dissenting opinion of WANCHOO and AYYANGAR JJ. was delivered by AYYANGAR J.

facts.text: Company offered to pay market value of land as at date of order by Panchapakesa Iyer J.

anchor.surface_text: But it is not necessary for the purpose of this case to decide that question, for the Company has offered to pay the market value of the land as at the date on which the order was passed by Panchapakesa lyer, J.
The Company then applied under s. 9 of the Act for an order directing the lessors to convey the site demised to the Company for a price to be fixed by the Court.

issues.text: Whether the Company is entitled under s. 9 of the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1922, notwithstanding the terms of the lease, to an order calling upon the lessors to sell the land demised

anchor.surface_text: Whether the terms of s. 9 of the Act infringe the fundamental right under Arts. 19 1 f and 31 1 of the Constitution, of the lessors, and s. 9 is on that account invalid.

arguments.claim: Stipulation in registered lease requiring delivery of vacant possession after dismantling constructions is a stipulation as to the erection of buildings within s.12 proviso, disentitling Company to s.9 benefit

anchor.surface_text: But the lessors contend that because of the stipulations in the deed of lease  which is registered under the law in force for registration of assurances  relating to the obligation of the tenant on the expiry of the lease to deliver vacant possession of the land after dismantling the constructions therein, the Company has by the terms of s. 12 disentitled itself to the benefit of s. 9 of the Act.

arguments.court_response: We are, for reasons presently to be set out, unable to uphold that contention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Stipulation relates to building but not 'as to the erection'; exception strictly construed

arguments.claim: Stipulation to deliver vacant possession after removing buildings is not a stipulation as to the erection of buildings under s.12 proviso

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges of the High Court have understood the words as to the erection of buildings occurring in the proviso as equivalent to a stipulation regarding the manner in which the building may be erected, the materials to be used, the area the building should cover and other details in relation to the construction of the building and as not apt to cover the case of a stipulation whereby the tenant undertakes to remove the buildings constructed by him on the termination of the tenancy and that was also the submission made to us by Mr. Setalvad on behalf of the respondent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: elivery of vacant possession of the site on the expiry of the period of the lease after removing the buildings is a stipulation as

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees stipulation not 'as to erection'; lists examples like size, materials

arguments.claim: Covenant to remove building and deliver vacant possession is stipulation relating to building but not 'as to the erection of building'

anchor.surface_text: A covenant in a lease which is duly registered that the tenant shall on expiry of the lease remove the building constructed by him and deliver vacant possession, is undoubtedly a stipulation relating to the building, but it is not a stipulation as to the erection of building.

arguments.claim: Exception in s.12 proviso must be strictly construed given object of Act and language

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the object of the Act, and the language used by the Legislature, the exception must be strictly construed, and a stipulation as to the erection of buildings would not, according to the ordinary meaning of the words used, encompass a stipulation to vacate and deliver possession of the land on the expiry of the lease without claiming to enforce the statutory rights conferred upon the tenant by s. 9.

arguments.claim: Stipulations protected by s.12 proviso are only those re size, nature, materials, purpose of buildings erected

anchor.surface_text: The stipulations not protected in s. 12 are only those in writing registered and relate to erection of buildings such as restrictions about the size and nature of the building constructed, the building materials to be used therein and the purpose for which the building is to be utilized.

arguments.claim: s.9 does not impose unreasonable restriction on right to hold/dispose property under Art.19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 1  which enables a tenant to purchase on determination of the lease the land of -the landlord is somewhat unusual. But it cannot be said that it imposes an unreasonable restriction upon the right of the landlord to hold and dispose of property within the meaning of Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: s.9 terms infringe fundamental rights under Arts.19(1)(f) and 31(1), hence invalid

This, it was submitted was unreasonable.

arguments.claim: Stipulation forbidding erection implies no compensation, same as requiring removal; both 'as to erection'

anchor.surface_text: If a stipulation forbidding erection of buildings and requiring their removal before surrendering possession of the site is conceded to be one in respect of erection of buildings-as has to be conceded, it is not possible to accept the construction that a stipulation for the removal of buildings which the lessee is permitted to erect and keep in the site only for the duration of the tenancy is any the less one in respect of erection of buildings.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes; removal not erection even if related

arguments.claim: Proviso saves stipulations affecting both s.3 compensation and s.9 purchase rights

anchor.surface_text: If as must be conceded the first limb of s. 12, save the statutory rights of tenants both under ss. 3 9 from the operation of any contract, it appears to us to stand to reason that the proviso which saves rights under contracts from the rights conferred by the Act should be construed to be coextensive with and operate on the same field as the opening portion of s. 12.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso limited to erection stipulations despite broader protection

holdings.text: A covenant in a lease which is duly registered that the tenant shall on expiry of the lease remove the building constructed by him and deliver vacant possession, is undoubtedly a stipulation relating to the building, but it is not a stipulation as to the erection of building.

anchor.surface_text: A covenant in a lease which is duly registered that the tenant shall on expiry of the lease remove the building constructed by him and deliver vacant possession, is undoubtedly a stipulation relating to the building, but it is not a stipulation as to the erection of building. Section 12 has manifestly been enacted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation distinguishes 'relating to building' from 'as to erection'; strict construction of proviso exception based on Act's object to protect tenants; lists examples like size, materials covered by proviso.

holdings.text: Section 9(1) which enables a tenant to purchase on determination of the lease the land of the landlord is somewhat unusual. But it cannot be said that it imposes an unreasonable restriction upon the right of the landlord to hold and dispose of property within the meaning of Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 1  which enables a tenant to purchase on determination of the lease the land of -the landlord is somewhat unusual. But it cannot be said that it imposes an unreasonable restriction upon the right of the landlord to hold and dispose of property within the meaning of Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to limited class of pre-extension leases for building construction; protects against unearned increment exploitation post-war rise; serves public interest in effectuating tenant-landlord understanding and conserving materials.

holdings.text: If the law is not invalid as offending Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution, no independent infringement of Art. 31(1) of the Constitution may be set up.

anchor.surface_text: If the law is not invalid as offending Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution, no independent infringement of Art. 31 1   of the Constitution may be set up.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.31(1) claim derivative; no deprivation without authority of law if valid under Art.19(1)(f).

holdings.text: But it is not necessary for the purpose of this case to decide that question, for the Company has offered to pay the market value of the land as at the date on which the order was passed by Panchapakesa Iyer, J.

anchor.surface_text: But it is not necessary for the purpose of this case to decide that question, for the Company has offered to pay the market value of the land as at the date on which the order was passed by Panchapakesa lyer, J.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided due to tenant's offer of current market value; unnecessary to adjudicate reasonableness of 1926 amendment price fixation.

holdings.text: Assuming that a provision fixing such compensation is unreasonable and therefore invalid, it would be clearly severable from the rest of the statute and would not affect the validity of the provision relating to acquisition by the tenant of the land demised by purchasing it from the landlord.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that a provision fixing such compensation is Unreasonable and therefore invalid, it would be clearly severable from the rest of the statute and would not affect the validity of the provision relating to acquisition by the tenant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical severability analysis; tenant's offer ensures market value payment.

holdings.text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were in error in their construction of the proviso to s. 12.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were in error in their construction of the proviso to s. 12. In this view the question as regards the constitutional validity of s. 9 would not really arise

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissenting view: stipulation bears on/relates to erection of buildings per textual/purposive reading reconciling with preamble; covers removal/demolition as affecting s.3 compensation right, thus s.9.

justification_sets.label: Section 9 Madras City Tenants' Protection Act 1922 support
